entry.title: Re: Handling of fixed expense rate per day
entry.content:
Hi @florian2636 ,

thanks for raising the question, as this is a common use case in the professional service industry. The way this is usually handled is via an additional resource (U-activity type and material). You can maintain this already in the planning of the work package and also maintain a project specific price. The cost rate of this U-activity type is usually 0 as the actual costs are maintained via the travel expenses as they occur. To record the actual amounts you can use the "Manage Direct Activity Allocation" or the respective API, e.g. if you have a separate tool for recording of actuals. The amount maintained is then showing up in "Manage Project Billing" with the defined sales price.

Best regards,

David

entry.title: 'DeltaStockRequest' payload link content
entry.content:
Hi Experts. 

I am reaching out to you with a question on peculiar S4 <-> SAP Ariba behavior. 

My Customer turned on inventory reservation between their S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP Ariba Buying. After a while they noticed that "some" system is trying to send "DeltaStockRequest" to SAP Ariba and these are stopped on SAP IS (transactions status 'failed'.

As far as the document itself is easy to explain with SAP Help - https://help.sap.com/docs/ariba/what-s-new-in-ariba-cloud-integration-gateway-2003-q1-2020-release-guide/functional-and-technical-changes-for-integration-to-support-displaying-unrestricted-stock-inventory-in-sap-ariba-procurement-solutions?q=DeltaStockRequest&locale=en-US&version=LATEST -  what causes a serious doubts is the content of the link shown in payload: 

<DeltaStockRequest xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" realmId="MyCustomersRealmID" systemId="QODCLNT002" transactionId="1733530145806" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="file:/C:/My_Work/CIG_ADDON_2018.12/DeltaStock.xsd"/>

I know there are similar cases in SAP Community but none of these explains:

- why there are some 'dummy' systems IDs 'hardcoded' in the link content,

- even if we agree that this is a 'dummy' link to be filled in with real system data - why isn't it the same for all cases? 

Do any of you  know a "bulletproof" explanation for it?

Thank you in advance!!

entry.title: SAP Integration with Concur Solutions: Default Configuration
entry.content:
SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (a.k.a. ICS, a.k.a. Native Integration) has been enhanced to simplify its setup. The enhancements are applicable for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025, and for S/4HANA 2025. In this blog post, I will explain the changes.

The ICS team has been propagating a Best Practice configuration for a long time. This Best Practice configuration was already indicated in the different wizards, e.g., when setting up the export of the first cost object type, a 4-level cost object hierarchy is defaulted. We've changed the configuration approach slightly: When you complete the System Connection wizard for the first time, a default configuration is set up for the integration activities you've selected for your system. So, in an ideal case, you don't have to go into the different wizards to set up a configuration. Connection set up and ICS configuration can be finished within 2 min.

There is no defaulting for

  • Budget Integration (Travel Request, Expense Report Obligation)
    Note: This option is only visible only in a system where Public Sector functionality has been activated.
  • Invoice Integration (Vendor, Invoice)
    Note: This option is not offered for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

How does the default configuration look?

I won't go into the details of every single wizard. But I want to give you an idea how the configuration looks.

Applicable for all integration activities

For the set up, we distinguish between a productive system and a non-productive system. For productive systems, batch jobs are scheduled for replication of master data and import of transactional data. For non-productive systems, manual export/import will be configured.

Applicable for cost object replication

  • Cost object replication is set up for Export Without Restrictions. Phased Roll-Out isn't active.
  • A name analysis of the available Concur lists is done to determine which list might be intended to store the cost objects. Setting up a list in Concur named SAP Integration Hierarchy or CostObjects for storing the cost objects is recommended.
  • The cost object hierarchy is set up with 4 levels: Logical System, Company Code, Cost Object Type, and Cost Object ID.

Applicable for the import of transactional data

  • Filtering of documents is set up to happen on the employee fields.
  • An analysis is done on the Concur field names to determine the filtering. 
  • Journal Entry Type is set to ER (Manual Expense Travel).
  • Posting Date is set to Today and recalculation of the posting date is enabled.

Applicable for the import of expense reports

  • The Report Number will be picked for creating the reference key.
  • Clearing by XREF fields is defaulted.
  • Payment Notification is set to active.
  • An analysis is done on the Concur field names to determine the cost object mapping for your specific Concur system.
  • A journal entry per expense report is expected to be created.
  • Supplier line items are not supposed to be condensed.

With this default configuration, the ICS team tries to reduce the effort that is required for setting up a working configuration for setups which are close to the Best Practice set up for Concur.

entry.title: SAP Integration with Concur Solutions: Alternative Reference System and Reference Key
entry.content:
In this blog post, I describe the enhancements that have been made for handling reference keys within SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (a.k.a. ICS, a.k.a. Native Integration), enhancements applicable for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025, and for SAP S/4HANA 2025. The enhancements impact the journal entry creation for expense reports and cash advances.

 

Changes affecting the Reference Key

When you look at a journal entry header, you see two fields containing the word Reference and are used to store a document identifier. The labeling differs slightly depending on the UI technology. In the Manage Journal Entry FIORI app, you have Document Reference ID and Original Reference Document.

 

In the transaction FB03, you have Reference and Reference Key.

For ICS, the leading field is the Original Reference Document/Reference Key. The Document Reference ID/Reference is a subset of the Reference Key. 

ICS constructs the Reference Key by picking an identifier of the Concur document, the revision ID of the Concur document, and the fixed value 1. Technically, the identifier of the Concur document and the revision ID are concatenated into a 10-character field (AWREF).  The fixed value is stored in a separate field. The fixed value is left out when constructing the content of the field Reference. For expense reports, ICS uses as identifier either the Report Number or Report Key. This can be configured within the Expense Report Import wizard, step Posting Settings. For Cash Advances, an artificial identifier is generated because Concur's Cash Advance ID is too long.

Starting with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508, we're offering the extension points BADI_CTE_FP_CB_AD_DETM_DOC_KEY and BADI_CTE_FP_CB_DETM_DOC_KEY. 

A similar option has been introduced for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025.

The extension points/BAdIs allow you to change the content of the AWREF field which is constructed from an identifier of the Concur document and the Concur document's revision ID (see above). This allows you, e.g., to remove spaces, replace letters with numbers etc.

Changes affecting the Reference System

To indicate the original system of an expense report or cash advance, ICS uses by default the System Key which is assigned to the Concur connection, e.g., 1,2,3 ...

Sometimes there is a need to use a specific reference or naming convention. That's why ICS offers a configuration option to define a value for the Reference System field. The configuration option is part of the System Connection wizard.

The system key is used as the default value for the field Reference System. When choosing the button Default Logical System, the current value of the Reference System field is replaced by the logical system. But you can also manually enter any 10-character string into the field.

Note: The Reference System field will become read-only after the first successful posting of an expense report or cash advance.

entry.title: SAP Integration with Concur Solutions: Improvements for Cost Object Replication
entry.content:
In this blog post, I describe the  enhancements that have been done for the cost object replication of SAP Integration with Concur Solutions (a.k.a. ICS, a.k.a. Native Integration), enhancements delivered with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508.

 

Improvements for Setting Up a Cost Object Hierarchy

To support hybrid scenarios, setting up cost object hierarchies became more flexible.

 

Standard List Levels

Let's first look at the pre-delivered levels available for defining a hierarchy for the cost object replication. A new standard level has been made available: Controlling Area. 

In total, ICS supports 6 list levels in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud out-of-the-box.

  • Logical System: This list level identifies the FI entity where the cost object comes from. As many customers are connecting several FI entities to the same Concur entity, the level is required to separate the cost objects of the different FI entities.
  • Company Code: The company code to which the cost object belongs
  • Cost Object ID: The ID of a cost object 
  • Cost Object Type: Cost objects of different types are oftentimes stored in the same list. The Cost Object Type level defines what type of ID is expected to be found on the Cost Object ID level.
  • Country/Region: This level determines to which country respectively region a cost object belongs
  • Controlling Area: This levels identifies the controlling area to which the cost object belongs. 

The recommended set up is a 4-level list consisting of Logical System, Company Code, Cost Object Type, and Cost Object ID levels. This list set up combines technical requirements, i.e., the need to separate cost objects from different systems, and usability requirements. Combined with a set up where at least the values Logical System and Company Code are defaulted from an employee's master data for cost allocation on the expense report, the employee only needs to enter a bare minimum of data, i.e., the employee only needs to pick a cost object type and a cost object. In many set ups, the employee's home cost center is defaulted for cost allocation. If the employee is supposed to fully book a trip on the home cost center, no input at all is required from the employee for specifying the cost allocation.

Note: The Concur UIs for the non-admin users are usually configured to hide the level Logical System. Companies that don't allow intercompany posting scenarios can also hide the level Company Code from the non-admin users.

 

Customer-Specific List Levels

Starting with the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, it is  possible to create customer-specific list levels in the Cost Object Export wizards, step Cost Object Hierarchy by pressing the button Manage Additional Fields. 

Press the + button to add a new level. You can enter a field name which allows you to identify the level when setting up a cost object hierarchy. The values from the columns Concur Item Code and Concur Item Name will be displayed in Concur when you need to pick a value for your customer-specific hierarchy level. 

 

Note: Unlike for S/4HANA on-Premise respectively S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, it is not possible to implement a BAdI/Extension Point to create values for the customer-specific levels in dependence of a given cost object, e.g., to define for cost center 4711 that the customer-specific level should get the code ABCD and to define for cost center 4712 that the customer-specific level should get the code XYZ.

Use the customer-specific level when setting up your cost object hierarchy:

Those are the enhancements that bring more flexibility to the set up of cost object hierarchies.

 

Extension Point

The extension point BADI_CTE_CB_COST_OBJECT was introduced to influence the cost object replication in a programmatic way. The extension point allows you to cover, among others, the following use cases:

  • Change the name of a cost object to meet language requirements when the current cost object name is different than the Concur default language.
  • Use this extension point to exclude individual objects instead of using the Single Objects Table in the Phased Rollout option or in the Exclude from Export option for the respective cost object export.

Specifically, you can

  • Change the name of a cost object in the Concur list
  • Exclude a cost object from the export so it is no longer considered
  • Delete a cost object that was previously exported to the Concur system

entry.title: What is the minimum capacity units (CU) to activate Object Store in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)?
entry.content:
Symptom: You are unsure of the number of capacity units (CU) required to activate Object Store in Business Data Cloud (BDC). 

Requirements: N/A.

Resolution: The minimum capacity units required to activate Object Store in BDC is 4150.05 CU (128 GB of SAP HANA memory). You can simulate this number in SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator. 

1) Open SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator

2) Select your Hyperscaler and Data Center

3) Click "Add" and double-click "SAP Datasphere"

4) Increase memory in "Compute" card until we have 128 GB

5) Add 1 block (minimum) in "Object Store Storage" card to activate this feature

6) Adjust parameters according to your needs in the simulator

7) View the final CU estimator for your business case

Image 1

 Image 2

Image 3

 

Image 4

entry.title: Why Does SAP B1 Allow Backdated Delivery Without Inventory? (Moving Average + Negative Stock Issue)
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

My colleague encountered a confusing behavior in SAP Business One 10.0 FP 2402 HF01 (SQL version) related to backdated deliveries and inventory logic. We'd like to ask for your insights.

Localization：China

Scenario:

  • In a test database, we used a brand-new item that had zero inventory.

  • On 2025/08/15, we posted a Goods Receipt of 1,000 units, unit cost = 1.00 (Posting Date = 2025/08/15).

  • Then we created two Delivery documents with Posting Dates set as:

    • 2025/08/01 (Delivered 1 unit)

    • 2025/08/10 (Delivered 1 unit)

To our surprise, both deliveries were posted successfully, even though the item had no inventory on those posting dates (08/01 & 08/10).

Accounting Observations:

  • The Inventory Audit Report, when filtered between 2025/08/01 ~ 2025/08/10, shows the item’s stock as -2.

  • The G/L report, for the same date range, shows a negative balance for the inventory account.

System Configuration:

Company-Level Settings:

  • ✅ Perpetual Inventory: Enabled

  • ✅ Item Valuation Method: Moving Average

  • ✅ “Allow stock release without item cost”: Checked

Document Settings (Administration → System Initialization → Document Settings):

  • ✅ Block Negative Inventory By: Warehouse

 

Questions:

  1. Why does the system allow delivery posting with backdated posting dates, even when no inventory existed on those dates?

  2. In this case, how is the Moving Average cost calculated and adjusted after the receipt is posted later?

  3. Are there any best practices or system controls to prevent this kind of unexpected delivery posting?

I’ve attached screenshots of the Inventory Audit Report and system configuration for reference.
Looking forward to your advice and insights—thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Work Zone: Integrate SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud content to SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
Hello, @Mukesh_SEIL @Nithesh_Yadav @Melvin11 .

I encountered the same issue where I was prompted to re-authenticate, just like you. I was able to resolve it, so I’d like to share what worked for me.

First, regarding the URL used in N5T_Starter_rt_apps, it should be:

S/4HANA Cloud Tenant ID.s4hana.ondemand.com

—not S/4HANA Cloud Tenant ID-api.s4hana.ondemand.com. The “-api” part was not necessary.

Next, in my case, I had configured trust settings using OpenID Connect, but I had mistakenly set the domain to the IPS URL, which caused SSO to fail and resulted in an error. By changing the domain to the IAS URL, SSO worked successfully.

I’m not sure if this is the same root cause for you, but I hope it helps as a reference.

entry.title: Re: Convergent Charging:Provider Contract Chage is not Ac...
entry.content:
Hi @soyuenyu 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

The issue you are facing typically means that although the provider contract change is processed, the activation step you require to update the activation date in CC is missing or not executed as expected.

Here are my recommended checks and actions you should carry out:

Please note that the Last Activation Date in CC is only set after the "Activate Provider Contract" step called PCCA is successfully triggered after product change or distribution from SOM.

Make sure that the activation step is included in your orchestration after the product change. Often, these types of issues arise if this step is skipped or is set as to "Irrelevant" in the ODI process schema.

It is important to note that if automation fails or activation remains blank, you still have the possibility to trigger contract activation directly in CC using the “chargingContractActivate” SOAP method for the specific contract.

Finally, confirm that the contract distribution to CC has fully completed and there are no failures in the integration logs between S/4 or SOM and CC.

To summarize, the Last Activation Date remains blank because the provider contract activation in CC hasn’t completed. Ensure that the activation call (PCCA) is executed as part of the product change process from SOM, and check ODI/monitoring logs for steps being skipped or marked irrelevant. If required, you can trigger the “chargingContractActivate” in CC by yourself to resolve the issue.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Restrict values in value help of basic uom while crea...
entry.content:
Hi @MalikaBathla 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through.

Please note, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, restricting the list of values in the Basic Unit of Measure (UoM) value help on the Product Master data (UI5 application) while following clean core principles presents limitations.

There is currently no released BADI or in-app extension point to directly filter the value help for Basic UoM in the public cloud, as you have already discovered.

Certain classic extensibility options like implicit enhancements or unreleased BADIs are not available in Public Cloud to ensure clean core compliance.

Configuration apps or custom logic to restrict value help options are also not available or supported for this specific area in the current Public Cloud offering.

However, as an alternative and in line with clean core approach my advice is to consider doing the following:

Consider using side-by-side extensions via SAP Business Technology Platform, where custom value helps or interfaces can be created externally and embedded but note that this does not replace the standard value help in SAP Fiori.

Also consider restricting UoMs via business process or work instructions, permission roles, or validation in integrated downstream processes. However, this does not limit the selectable value help.

To summarize, there is no supported clean core way to restrict standard Basic UoM value help in Product Master in S/4HANA Public Cloud at this time. Your options are limited to process controls or side-by-side extensions.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: From Application Logging to Cloud Logging: Service Innovation Guide
entry.content:
Hi @Ghazanfar ,

the deprecation date for CPEA contracts was published via Discovery Center and is July 31, 2025. This means

For running contracts (signed before deprecation date): 

  • Customers have entitlement to use the service - current instances and create new instances until their next renewal date.

New or re-newed contracts (signed after the deprecation date):

  • Customers have no entitlement to subscribe to the service 
  • The service won’t appear in their entitlement list
  • Existing service instances (from previous contract periods) will stay operational and active

entry.title: Re: Can we set multi scaled conditions in SAP TM Rate table?
entry.content:
Hi @LINGLINGLING_CN 

Yes, you are correct the grouping strategy is the grouping rule defined in the charge calculation sheet in SAP TM. To ensure you achieve daily aggregated pricing per lane or weight, while keeping the 1 FU = 1 FO structure, I advice you set up your calculation sheet as follows:

Here are the steps to help you define the grouping rule:

First, in your Calculation Sheet: Define grouping keys: From Location, To Location, and Calendar Day. Then set Calculation Rule to “Rate Based”, Aggregation Mode to “Day”, Calculation Base = “Weight”.

Secondly, in the calculation sheet, ensure you assign the grouping rule to group Freight Orders by lane (From/To location) and shipping day. This ensures that all FOs for a given lane or day are aggregated and total weight is used to calculate the base rate charge.

Finally, Your rate table should have condition keys for From Location, To Location, Calendar Day, and scale for Weight.

This setup will aggregate your daily charges for each lane based on the total FO weight, so even with separate FUs or FOs for each order, the pricing per lane or day is consolidated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Embedding Trust: Watermarking for AI Compliance and Lifecycle Management
entry.content:
Introduction

As AI-generated content becomes deeply integrated into enterprise workflows, ensuring authenticity, traceability, and compliance is more critical than ever. AI-generated documents, reports, media files, and communication content are increasingly driving decisions, automation, and customer interactions. As a result, organizations are no longer just creating content—they're responsible for governing it across its entire lifecycle.

Watermarking—once a niche solution primarily used for digital rights management—is now emerging as a key enabler of AI content governance. By embedding information directly into content files—such as their creation source, generation method, AI model, or associated policy metadata—watermarks help ensure that AI outputs are verifiable, policy-aware, and audit-ready.

In this blog, we explore the role of watermarking in enabling AI compliance, supporting lifecycle management, and building trusted AI content ecosystems at scale. We will cover the current challenges enterprises face, how watermarking works, and what’s needed for watermarking to evolve with generative AI.

 

 

Compliance by Design: A Necessity for Watermarking AI-Generated Content

AI-generated content is increasingly subject to regulatory and corporate governance. Legal frameworks such as the EU AI Act, California AI Transparency Act, China Measures for Labeling of AI-Generated Synthetic Content and GDPR, alongside internal audit and information governance policies, now require that content produced by AI be:

  • Explicitly labelled as AI-generated
  • Traceable to its source
  • Managed in line with legal retention policies
  • Auditable for integrity and responsible use

Beyond legal compliance, enterprises must ensure that AI-generated content can be classified, archived, audited, and ultimately destroyed based on business rules. This is where information lifecycle management (ILM) comes in. From creation to retention, archiving to deletion, each stage of content use must be policy-driven and secure.

Traditional metadata alone is not sufficient to meet these goals—metadata can be stripped or altered. Watermarking offers a more durable, embedded approach to ensure content governance is inherently built into the content itself.

 

What Is Watermarking

Watermarking is the process of embedding additional information—either visible or invisible—into digital content. This information can be extracted later to verify origin, track usage, or enforce compliance. Watermarks can include model identifiers, timestamps, legal classifications, or lifecycle metadata.

Methods of Watermarking

Watermarks can be embedded in various ways depending on the content type:

 

 

  • Images: Frequency‑domain methods such as Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) and matrix‑factorization techniques like Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) enable imperceptible watermark embedding while preserving visual fidelity. 

 

  • Videos: Frame-based watermarks allow tracking across transformations and streaming.
  • Text: Emerging techniques embed watermarks in AI‑generated text by manipulating token‑selection patterns or introducing subtle semantic perturbations that remain imperceptible to readers.
  • Audio: Watermarks can be applied in the frequency or time domain (e.g., using spread spectrum or echo hiding techniques), allowing resilient tracking through compression, filtering, and re-recording.
  • PDF files: Watermarks can be embedded in content streams or structure elements without altering visual layout.
  • Tabular data: In structured data such as CSV or Excel files, watermarking can be applied by subtly modifying statistical properties or introducing pattern-based noise within numerical precision thresholds—enabling detection without compromising data utility.

 

Categories of watermarking

Watermarks can be categorized in two main ways: visibility and resilience to manipulation.

       1. By Visibility:

  • Visible watermarks: Logos, seals, or text overlays that indicate ownership or status.
  • Invisible watermarks: Algorithmically embedded data that is imperceptible to the human eye but can be detected programmatically.

      2. By Resilience to Manipulation:

  • Robust watermarks: Designed to survive edits like cropping, compression, scaling, or format changes.
  • Fragile watermarks: Easily removed when content is altered, useful for detecting tampering or unauthorized modification.

 

Watermarks & Metadata

While both watermarking and metadata aim to enrich digital files with useful context, they serve different purposes and come with unique trade-offs. Metadata is easily accessible and widely supported across systems, making it ideal for fast retrieval, tagging, and classification. However, it can be removed, altered, or lost during file transfers, format conversions, or malicious tampering.

On the other hand, watermarking embeds information directly into the content itself—making it more persistent and tamper-resistant. It remains intact even if a file is renamed, copied, or stripped of its metadata.

Used together, they form a powerful combination:

  • Metadata enables automation and policy-driven governance,
  • Watermarks provide long-term traceability and authenticity—even across systems.

 

 

Applications of AI Watermarking

Watermarking serves a wide range of compliance and security functions in the context of AI. It enables enterprises to embed critical information at the moment of content generation and retrieve it later to verify its legitimacy, origin, and policy alignment.

Content Provenance and Authentication

One of the most impactful applications is authenticity verification. Watermarks can confirm whether a piece of content—image, document, or video—was generated by AI, when it was created, and under what policy. This is essential for trust and transparency, especially in regulated industries or public-facing communications.

Watermarks are also crucial for verifying the authenticity and ownership of digital artworks, particularly in NFTs, protecting intellectual property. They can be also used to verify the integrity of legal, financial, and HR documents, ensuring compliance and audit trail reliability.

Watermarking for Lifecycle Governance

Beyond detection, watermarks help enforce Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) policies automatically. At each stage of a file's life, watermarks enable smart, compliant handling:

  • Creation: Embed watermarks at the point of generation to record the origin and purpose.
  • Retention: Encode legal tags or policy rules to guide how long a file must be kept.
  • Audit: Watermarks track changes and access history, supporting audit trails.
  • Archiving: Even in long-term storage, watermarks preserve authenticity and ownership.
  • Destruction: Watermarks indicate when deletion is permitted and record that action as proof of compliance.

 

 

 

The Strategic Importance of Watermarking

Watermarking is more than a technical solution—it’s a strategic enabler for enterprise-grade AI governance. As organizations generate increasing volumes of AI content, ensuring responsibility, auditability, and control becomes essential. Invisible watermarking provides the foundation for this shift, turning untraceable content into self-describing, policy-aware assets.

From a business perspective, watermarking brings several key advantages:

  • Proactive Compliance with AI Regulations
    Watermarks help enterprises meet emerging legal requirements, such as those outlined in the EU AI Act, by embedding model identity, generation source, and disclosure metadata directly into files. This enables content-level traceability and accountability at scale.
  • Enhanced Data Integrity and Auditability
    Embedded watermarks offer a tamper-resistant record of content origin, usage policy, and lifecycle events—supporting internal audits, external reporting, and security reviews.
  • Seamless Integration with SAP ILM and IRM Workflows
    Watermarking aligns naturally with SAP's Information Lifecycle Management and Information Retention Manager systems. It enables automated decision-making for retention, archiving, or deletion based on metadata embedded at the time of creation.
  • Metadata-Driven File Classification and Governance
    Watermarked content can carry its own classification, such as document type or sensitivity level, enabling intelligent automation of compliance actions without relying solely on external metadata or manual tagging.
  • Self-Aware Content for Smarter Automation
    Perhaps most importantly, watermarking empowers content to become self-aware—capable of communicating its own identity, rules, and restrictions. This makes it possible to build more adaptive, intelligent document governance systems that respond in real time to compliance needs.

In short, watermarking transforms AI-generated content from a potential risk into a managed, compliant, and trustworthy asset—one that supports both operational efficiency and long-term governance goals.

 

Outlook: The Evolution of Watermarking in the Generative AI Era

As generative AI continues to advance, watermarking must evolve to meet the growing demands of scale, robustness, and interoperability.

  • Scalability: Future watermarking systems must support high-volume content generation and real-time applications such as streaming media and cloud-native pipelines.
  • Robustness: As AI-generated content proliferates, watermarks must be resilient against a wide range of manipulations — from basic operations like compression, cropping, and format conversion, to more advanced challenges such as screenshots and adversarial attacks. Crucially, they must remain detectable across diverse content types and evolving AI output formats.
  • Standards and Interoperability: One major challenge is the lack of unified, industry-wide standards. To address this, the adoption of open standards like C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity) is critical. Open-source solutions such as Meta’s VideoSeal and DeepMind’s SynthID for text/image watermarking are also paving the way for broader adoption and transparency.

In short, watermarking must become more intelligent, resilient, and standardized to remain a trusted foundation for AI content governance across industries.

 

 

Conclusion: Authenticity Matters in the Age of AI

As AI becomes a core part of enterprise systems, the ability to verify, trace, and govern content becomes essential. Watermarking provides a foundational layer of trust—ensuring that content is not only intelligent, but also accountable.

In the era of generative AI, authenticity is not optional—it’s a requirement.

 

[References]

https://artificialintelligenceact.eu/

https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2023/10/30/executive-order-on-the-safe-secure-and-trustworthy-development-and-use-of-artificial-intelligence/

https://community.sap.com/topics/information-lifecycle-management

entry.title: Re: Delivery document type OUTB has the wrong document ca...
entry.content:
Hi @basha_shaik7 

The error message you received indicates that there is a mismatch in the document category assignment between ERP and EWM systems during delivery document integration.

Such error messages could be triggered by:

In SAP Extended Warehouse Management, delivery document types are mapped to specific document categories representing business scenarios e.g., shipping confirmation orders, physical delivery orders etc.

Your ERP delivery type OUTB is currently configured or mapped to the document category PDO but EWM expects it to be SPC for your business process.

The fact that it works in your sandbox but not development indicates a configuration difference or missing mapping in the IMG activity:

To locate the issue, this is what I advice you to verify and do:

Check Configuration in Both Systems. Compare the document type to category mapping for OUTB in sandbox vs. development.

Make sure ERP delivery type OUTB is assigned document category SPC in EWM customizing for your development landscape.

If you need to adjust the Mapping, then consider the following:

Change or add the mapping so that OUTB is assigned to the expected SPC document category. This can be done in SPRO under the path above.

Check Business Configuration Sets or Switches. There might be Business Configuration sets or system parameters active in Sandbox but missing in Development controlling document type mappings or EWM integration behaviour. Verify your Business Configuration sets or transport requests related to EWM integration to ensure consistency across systems.

Finally, check your Transport and Consistency. Please ensure that all related customizing and transport requests are moved correctly from Sandbox to Development to avoid configuration gaps.

To summarize, the integration error arises because ERP delivery type OUTB’s document category mapping is inconsistent or incorrect for your EWM system. Adjust the mapping of document OUTB to the document category SPC in your Development system’s SPRO configuration for EWM integration delivery processing to fix the issue.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition – Convergent Invoicing Connector
entry.content:
SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition – Convergent Invoicing Connector

New Feature

Public Cloud

August 2025

What’s the New Feature?

  • A new out-of-the-box connector interfacing Component Convergent Invoicing of solution SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, contract accounting and invoicing (herein called Convergent Invoicing).
  • Providing connectivity for sending already-rated or already-priced transactions to Convergent Invoicing, for accounting and revenue recognition purposes.
  • All configurable in graphical user interface, for ease of use and quick time to value.
  • Using standard SAP ODATAV4 interface and adapting to the APIs evolution.

What Kind of Use Cases Does it Enable?

Whenever there are sales events happening, for example at a Point of Sales, Service Delivery Platform, or E-commerce Platform there will be a need to match generated sales orders (priced or rated transactions) with the actual payments or payment confirmations (from credit cards/payment gateways, and banks). This matching is needed to properly recognize the revenue, make postings to the General Ledger and have proof of where each revenue instance came from for the tax authority auditors. While the actual matching is an accounting responsibility of the SAP S/4HANA system, it relies on the mediation system to provide accurate sales data originating in the ordering system. 

SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition, needs to collect the sales orders from any customer data sources (e.g., residing on the public internet or customer premises), validate the information and prepare the data before sending it to Convergent Invoicing as Billable Items (BITs).

Preparing typically involves identifying the responsible business partner/contract account(s) and retrieving the product definitions to determine which BITs have to be created - think of a bundled product that is sold as a single order but requires multiple BITs for accounting purposes. Enriching the raw input with this data allows mediation to then create the proper BIT(s) including any supplementary BITs for tax, payments, etc. which are to be sent to Convergent Invoicing. See chapter “Mediation Functions Overview” for a more comprehensive view of the preparations.

Example of customer landscape where sales orders are mediated as Billable Items into Convergent Invoicing.

Example of Billable Item contents.

How Can it Be Used in Real-Life Scenarios?

Select the function amongst the available SAP forwarding functions.

Drag-and-drop it into the stream editor and connect to functions delivering prepared payloads.

Configure your data structure and data mappings directly within the function, no code needed.

As per the Convergent Invoicing Billable Item API1 (Create Billable Item), the following BIT categories and structures are supported in the GUI: Main, Payment, RatedConsumption, Tax, Text and AdditionalParameter.

New Connector Technical Features

The technical features below allow the implementer to focus on the functional side of the use case and leave the integration details to SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition. These capabilities ensure the messages are sent reliably to the targets and with full flexibility to manage any exceptions, with:

  • Built-in retry option.
  • At-least-once transaction safety.
  • Respond-async option allows for immediate asynchronous acknowledgement from Convergent Invoicing.
  • Management of response messages in separate stream via Response Handling feature.
  • Utilizes batch API for better performance.
  • Updated Preview capability allows testing the connection to Convergent Invoicing during development of the stream.  

Overview of operational settings.

Mediation Functions Overview

Below are some examples of processing steps that can be performed within SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition streams to validate and enrich raw source data making it readily usable by downstream systems.

Mapping of External Transaction Record Format to BIT Format 

SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition provides a flexible mapping layer where external protocol and data formats (e.g., CSV, Excel, XML, JSON) can be mapped to internal record format and then converted to other protocol and formats, in this case the BIT (Billable Item) format over ODATAV4.

Master Data Enrichment

To correctly categorize or group the BIT record, the record needs to be enriched based on external meta data. This could be done through lookups to database or external SOAP or REST APIs.

Record Splitting

An incoming transaction may contain multiple billable transactions, in which case the transaction needs to be split into several BITs so that they can be grouped, aggregated, and billed separately.

Validation

Examples of validation rules: mandatory fields present, values within expected ranges, lookups have matches, consistency counts of records within files. Invalid records are sent to a built-in Data Correction facility, where a Data Steward can correct and reprocess the records.

Aggregation

Where multiple partial transactions need to be correlated and aggregated into one BIT. 

Deduplication

When duplicate transactions need to be removed prior to loading BITs into Convergent Invoicing. The deduplication functionality of SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition is highly scalable

Scalable Creation of BITs

SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition, provides a robust and performant solution for the creation of BITs. BIT creation can be scaled by parallel loading of BITs into Convergent Invoicing.

Conclusion

This new feature enables a new family of industry-agnostic use cases for SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition, by natively connecting to Convergent Invoicing. These use cases can be found across all industries, as they involve collecting and mediating priced/rated transactions downstream for revenue recognition purposes and compliance with tax authorities. Thus, significantly increasing the addressable market of SAP Convergent Mediation by DigitalRoute, public cloud edition and the value it can provide to customers.

Key benefits:

  1. Faster Time to Value: Deploy the connector rapidly due to its out-of-the-box design and user-friendly controls.
  2. Standardization and Interoperability: Built on SAP API standards, future-proofing your data integration architecture.
  3. Operational Assurance: Reliable transaction and delivery assurance eliminate critical data loss in complex, high-volume contexts.
  4. Compliance and Audit Readiness: All data is validated and auditable, supporting stringent regulatory and tax compliance requirements.
  5. Industry-Agnostic: Applicable across any sector needing automated, compliant quote-to-cash processes.

Further readings

SAP CI/FICA Cloud Public Billable Item Creation API link1: https://api.sap.com/api/CABILLABLEITEM_0001/resource/Billable_Item

SAP Convergent Invoicing Connector Documentation (DigitalRoute InfoZone):

SAP S/4HANA for convergent invoicing - Usage Engine Cloud Edition Documentation - InfoZone

Convergent Invoicing Documentation (help.sap.com/s4_ce_brim):

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/1a561330b0fe4990b9566655770746dd/c893d0eadc7e4c4a9123ee6b9502da85.html?version=latest

GET Call details:
url: https://notifications.cfapps.<time-zone>.hana.ondemand.com/v2/NotificationType.svc
Header: x-csrf-token: fetch
                Authorization: Bearer <access_token from the previous call>

If somebody has an experience with that case, I would appreciate any help and instructions.

Best regards, 
Vladyslav

entry.title: Re: VAT number doesn't print on invoice
entry.content:
Hello @ceciliajohansson7768 

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this typically occurs because the invoice form template is configured to display the VAT registration number only for specific countries, such as EU members, AU, VN, or when the tax ID is categorised under VAT Registration Number.

For countries such as Japan, Indonesia, and the UAE, the customer master often includes different tax ID categories like Corporate Number, NPWP, and TRN. If the form only searches for the VAT Registration Number, it won’t show these.

Recommended checks and fixes:

  1. In Manage Business Partner Master Data, verify that the bill-to party has the correct tax number recorded under the appropriate tax number category for that country.y.
  2. Review the invoice form in Maintain Form Templates under form logic. If the script or binding limits output to certain countries or VAT-only categories, modify it to also include the relevant country-specific tax ID.
  3. Template assignment – Make sure the correct form variant is selected for those countries in Output Management.

Check below SAP documentation

SAP Help – Tax Number Categories and VAT Registration Number

Maintain Form Templates-SAP Help

Maintaining Tax Number for Business Partners-SAP Help

Creating and Using a Custom Form Template-SAP Help

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: How to use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator?
entry.content:
**Updated August 2025**

Welcome to our blog series focused on the SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator. 

This guide provides a comprehensive, step-by-step approach to help you estimate the capacity units (CU) needed for your business case (before purchasing) or how you can distribute them across your solution components (after signing a contract).

Remember that BDC is available only through the subscription commercial model, which means you pay a fixed price for a specific quantity of CU. The price varies on how many CU you need.

Furthermore, once licensed, BDC offers flexibility in quota assignment. This means that, if you need to allocate more CU to SAP Datasphere, you can reduce the number of licenses in SAP Analytics Cloud, and vice-versa*. 

This series has 4 parts as follows: 

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Analytics Cloud (coming soon)
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Datasphere (coming soon)
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Databricks (coming soon)

What's SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator? This estimator tool helps you calculate the number of capacity units required for each SAP BDC capacity service, as well as the total amount needed.

What are capacity units? Capacity Units (CU) are the metric used to allocate storage and compute resources within the BDC solution. The criteria for calculating CU vary depending on the service component:

  • For SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), CU differs by license type and corresponding quantities (SAC BI, SAC Planning Standard, or SAC Planning Professional)
  • For SAP Datasphere, CU depends on multiple factors such as Data Lake usage, storage, memory, and more
  • For SAP Databricks, CU is based on various measures including storage, serverless SQL compute, and SAP Object Store requests.

SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator Home Screen

* Note: This does not apply to SAP Business Warehouse Private Cloud Edition, as its capacity unit quota is determined by your contract with SAP. Also, for SAP Databricks, although you assign a quota amount, usage can exceed this number since billing is based on actual consumption rather than the assigned quota.

Source: Administer SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: Re: Partial Customer Project Invoice Request
entry.content:
Hello @KCPN 

Yes, you can generate a partial customer project invoice request through various methods without editing each item individually.

  • Create Billing Request app; Select the project/WBS item and specify the partial amount or percentage to bill.
  • Billing Plan at Sales Order level; If integrated with SD, define percentage or milestone billing in Manage Sales Orders.
  • API-based partial billing; Use A_ProjectBillingRequest or A_CustomerProject to automate creation of partial billing requests.
  • Billing Profile configuration: In Maintain Billing Profiles, set rules to support partial invoicing by default.
  • Revenue recognition milestones: If applicable, trigger partial invoice requests through milestone events.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Can Joule AI Make SAP Readiness Check & Process Insights Smarter?
entry.content:
Hi Tommy, 

Thanks for sharing this,  I’m looking after the Joule topic in SAP Signavio and would be very interested in the outcome of your research. Your exploration touches on some important areas for how Joule could evolve. To put it simply, Joule needs capabilities (features/skills) to be developed for each specific use case. Right now, Joule in Signavio is available only to a selected group of customers via our Early Adopter Care (EAC) program, with a defined set of features and skills.

On your points: Integrated approach – Joule embedded directly in tools for live Q&A and guidance> Could you elaborate more on the type of questions and the expected outcomes? If the goal is to ask about the product itself or its functionality, Joule can already do this via document grounding from the SAP Help Portal content. If the goal is to provide data-driven analysis or recommendations from those tools in real time, that would require dedicated features/skills tied to the relevant APIs.

Standalone approach – Central Joule portal for uploading exported tool data for AI summaries> Joule recently introduced the ability to upload documentation (only when certain features are invoked), but as far as I know, it does not yet support processing arbitrary exported datasets from other tools for analysis. That would be a new capability to scope and design.

For the other ideas you mentioned, like: Training Joule using Signavio Process Explorer as a knowledge source Enabling Joule to learn a customer’s processes over time to adjust benchmarks and avoid false alarms I’d be happy to connect so we can explore these in more detail. These touch on areas like personalised context, benchmark adaptation, and custom knowledge integration, which are highly relevant for Signavio’s long-term AI roadmap. Let’s sync up, I can share the current state of Joule in Signavio, and we can map your ideas to what’s technically possible now vs. what would require new feature development.

entry.title: Re: Where can I add the tax code in the SAP public cloud?
entry.content:
Hello @Zhijun_Xie 

You cannot freely create tax codes like in on-premise systems, but you can add and configure them within the available scope for your country or region.

  • Tax codes are country-specific and must comply with the country’s tax procedure delivered by SAP. Note, you can’t change the procedure itself
  • You can generate new tax codes for your company's country, but only within the tax procedure designated for that country.
  • The system enforces permitted tax type combinations, reporting codes, and percentage limits based on the local content provided.

Configuration in S4HANA Public Cloud

 Define Tax Codes for Sales and Purchases

  1. Go to: Manage Your Solution → Configure Your Solution.
  2. Application Area: Financial Accounting → Tax on Sales/Purchases.
  3. SSCUI ID: Define Tax Codes for Sales and Purchases.
  4. Steps:
    • Select the country.
    • Create a new two-character tax code.
    • Assign tax type (input/output), percentage rate, and validity dates.
    • For input tax, link to the appropriate tax account from SSCUI – Assign Tax Accounts).
    • Save and transport (in Public Cloud, activation is immediate).

Check the documentations below

  • SAP Learning-Define Tax Codes (Public Cloud) 
  • SAP Best Practice- Tax on Sales and Purchases 

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer in SAP S/4HANA OP/Private Cloud

entry.title: How to store long Supplier Invoice Reference Numbers in SAP S/4HANA ERP Products
entry.content:
How Official Document Numbers (ODN) Framework can help customers to store long Supplier Invoice Reference Numbers in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA

 

 

In my last Blogposts I introduced you into How Official Document Numbering helps to fulfil the Polish KSeF Requirements in S4HANA Public Cloud and also informed you about How you can manage Polish KSeF Requirement in SAP ... - SAP Community

 

With this new Blog I´d like to give you an example of how the new ODN Framework can help you to store Supplier Invoice Reference Numbers, larger than 16 digits, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA.

 

In the following example we will focus on Poland as country, as this is a common scenario there. But the new ODN Framework is not restricted to any country and can be used everywhere.

 

 

Configuration

1.  Maintain Official Document Number Types - Transaction: “ODNTYP”

 

Create the ODN Types (Examples):

  • ZLINV - Long Invoice Number

 

 

 

 

2.  Map Official Document Number Type to Internal Type
- Transaction: “ODNINTTYP”

 

Map your custom official document number type to the SAP-delivered internal official document number type so that the system can correctly derive the official document number within your consuming application.

Procedure

  • In your configuration environment, search for and open the Map Official Document Number Type to Internal Type activity.
  • In the ODN Country/Region field, type PL and choose Apply.
  • Choose New Entries.
  • In the ODN Internal Type field, choose the SAP-delivered internal official document number type LIRN.
  • In the ODN Type field, choose your custom official document number type; for example, LINV.
  • Save your changes.

 

 

3.  Configure Official Document Number Type Characteristics TA: “ODNTYPC”

 

Set the properties of your custom official document number type, such as its length and how it is processed.

 

Procedure

    • In your configuration environment, search for and open the Configure Official Document Number Type Characteristics activity.
    • In the ODN Country/Region field, type PL and choose Apply.
    • In the Assign Official Document Number Types to Country step, choose New Entries and add your custom official document number types from above.
    • Choose the new entry you have added for your custom official document number type and then go to User Interface Settings.
    • In the ODN Length field, enter the length you need, for example 200 digits.
    • Go to Process Specific Settings.
    • Choose New Entries and add the following entry:

 

  • For ZLINV:

 

 

 

  • For MM_SUPPLIER_INV:

 

 

4.  Example – Supplier Invoice via transaction MIRO

 

  • Enter the invoice relevant data and then press “Additional Fiscal Data”

 

 

  • Now Enter the Official Document Numbers relevant for your business in Poland (KSeF and Long Invoice Number, if needed):

 

 

Data Access via CDS Views:

Process

CDS View

SD Billing

I_BillingDocumentODN

FI Customer/Supplier invoice

I_AccountingDocumentODN

MM Supplier Invoice

I_SupplierInvoiceODN

 

 

 

The Business Processes and SAP Help Documentation for our example in Poland can be found here:

Business Area

Supported Business Processes

Description

Sourcing and Procurement

Configuring Long Invoice Number (PLLIN) for Supplier Invoices

You can manually maintain the official document number in supplier invoices. The system validates this value based on the properties maintained in the configuration.

 

 

Availability

The solution shown above is available for:

  • SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Public Edition (current Release)
  • SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA Versions 1709 – 2025.

 

Regarding SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA, there are two ways of consuming the solution.

  1. You can install the next feature Package for your S/4HANA Solution
  2. You can install the notes which have been released recently:
  • In this case refer to the note collection in SAP Note 3565339 for additional details and also note 3639622 - ODN Internal Type - LIRN

 

 

I hope that I was able to provide you a good overview about how use the new ODN Framework could support you to store long invoice references.

 

Thanks,

 

See you next time!

 

Christian Seelinger

entry.title: Re: OData Service — Data Retrieved in Debug, but HTTP 500...
entry.content:
Hi @ashokkandel 

In reference to the comment made earlier, the HTTP 500 error you see after pressing F8 to finish the request, despite correct data in debug, usually points to an issue occurring during the OData serialization or response handling phase.

There are a few common causes and these include the following:

Data type mismatch in metadata or runtime data. Even small discrepancies between your MPC metadata definitions and the actual runtime data can cause failures during response serialization.

Null or unexpected values. If any field in your response data is null or contains unexpected values e.g., empty strings for numeric fields the OData framework might raise internal errors.

Large payload or buffering issues. Very large datasets or inefficient buffering could cause memory exceptions leading to HTTP 500 errors.

Incorrect method implementation. It is important to note that sometimes, not properly handling deep structure fields or associations in GET_ENTITYSET or GET_ENTITY can cause runtime errors.

Backend system parameters. Parameters related to runtime memory and shared objects size e.g., abap or shared_objects_size_MB may be too low, which may cause internal issues when the service tries to serialize and deliver the data.

 

I would recommend that you:

First, check your /IWFND/ERROR_LOG as recommended by SAP Note 1797736 to get detailed error information.

Validate that your MPC metadata exactly matches your underlying DDIC structure and that no incompatible types or missing fields exist.

Ensure you add runtime null checks and default values in your GET_ENTITY and GET_ENTITYSET method implementations.

Reduce the size of the dataset returned for initial testing by limiting filter conditions and Increase runtime memory parameters if needed.

Test your OData service calls via external clients like Postman to confirm if the issue is related to UI/browser specifics.

The summary is that this error is fairly common when metadata and runtime data are out-of-sync or when encountering unexpected data during serialization.

Hope this helps.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: BTP Cloud Foundry Consumed by all spaces exceeds any...
entry.content:
Hi @CDN_Steve 

This memory discrepancy likely points to one or more of the following causes:


It is important to note that sometimes, apps or service instances that are no longer active remain allocated memory without being visible in the current space stats. These can consume memory reserved by your org quota.


Memory may be reserved or consumed by other spaces in the org that are not visible in your current space view, or by the org-level quota that includes reserved buffers.


Beyond user apps, Cloud Foundry runtime and platform components may reserve memory quota counted against the org quota but not attributed to individual spaces or apps.


It is possible that the memory usage figures are stale or inconsistent due to cloud platform glitches; previously reported issues may clear themselves over time but require investigation by SAP support.

I would recommend you consider doing the following:

List all spaces and apps across the org. Use CLI commands for example cf spaces, cf apps –all or cloud platform console to verify if any other spaces or apps are consuming memory unexpectedly.

Check service instances:
Confirm if any bound service instances consume memory quota.

Review quota assignments. Ensure to verify the quota plans assigned at org and space levels and any reserved buffers.

Restart or scale down unused apps. Please note, if orphaned apps exist, stop or delete them to release memory.

If the issue still exists, provide logs and memory usage snapshots to SAP support for deeper platform investigation.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud Outbound IP Ranges
entry.content:
Hi @dogukanpadel 

To obtain the egress IP address ranges for your SAP Public Cloud instance needed for bank integration user and IP mapping, here is the recommended approach:

SAP Public Cloud which includes Cloud Foundry egress IPs are managed by the underlying cloud infrastructure and IPs can change over time. Examples are the Hyperscalers.

SAP provides region-specific IP ranges for some services and environments via official documentation and GitHub projects, for example:

SAP BTP Kyma Runtime egress IP utility scripts to discover live egress IPs.

SAP Help Portal pages listing SAP HANA Cloud and Integration Suite IPs.

For your specific SAP Public Cloud tenant, you can check SAP Service Interfaces and Network documentation specific for your region.

You also have the option to contact SAP Cloud Operations or your SAP Account team to request the official IP ranges assigned to your tenant or landscape. Keep in mind these IPs may change with platform updates, so ongoing communication or subscription to SAP notices is advisable.

If you have Kubernetes or Cloud Foundry access within your SAP environment, you can also run scripts or tools that query live egress IP addresses to capture current outbound IPs used by your applications.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Planned Inventory active in LS03N, how to clear yello...
entry.content:
The yellow triangle indicates that planned inventory is still active for the bin.

Even if all inventory records are cleared, the system may still show the bin as blocked for inventory due to:

  • Incomplete clearing of inventory documents
  • Residual entries in tables like LAGP or LINP
  • System inconsistencies after manual or partial clearing

Go to LX22, tick the boxes Not counted or Partially counted bins so that, you may find an inventory document still linked to the bin even if LS03N shows it as cleared. Check table LAGP for the bin, field IVIVO (Inventory active indicator) may still be set. If IVIVO = X, the system considers the bin as planned for inventory. Check SAP note 824904 which provides a correction report and it updates internal fields and clears the yellow triangle. But as cautioned in the note, you should be very careful before running the report. Also, check for SAP note 2124215 which gives two resolutions.

entry.title: Re: Adaptation Project - Select application - Blank
entry.content:
HI @krish96 

The reason can related to various areas. A few of them are:

It can refer to system or tooling limitations. Some apps cannot currently be configured or extended via Adaptation Projects in Business Application Studio and require SAP Web IDE instead.

It can also be missing required SAP UI5 versions or platform components. The apps must meet minimum UI5 version requirements which is usually 1.56 or higher and run on supported SAP front-end framework versions.

The Workspace or project context can also be a trigger. Note that the Adaptation Project wizard only shows applications available in the current workspace that meet specific criteria.

Permissions or authorizations issues that can also prevent the loading of applications.

There are some known UI or feature restrictions. Some new features in BAS may cause empty application lists, requiring updates or workarounds such as regenerating the entire project or adjusting config files.

However, you can try solving that by:

Verifying the app you want to adapt is compatible with Adaptation Projects. This can be Fiori elements Object Page or List Page.

Ensuring your environment supports the UI5 version and system components.

You can try using SAP Web IDE if your app is not visible in BAS Adaptation Projects.

Checking your workspace and system authorizations.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: VAT number doesn't print on invoice
entry.content:
Some root causes are

  • SAP often uses country-dependent logic in the invoice form templates (SmartForms, Adobe Forms, or Output Management). Some countries (e.g., EU members) require VAT numbers on invoices by law, so the template includes them. For countries like Japan, Indonesia, UAE, the template may omit VAT numbers unless explicitly configured.
  • The Customer Master Record (BP) may not have the Tax Number 1 or VAT Registration Number maintained for these countries. If the field is blank or not mapped correctly, it won’t print.
  • SAP’s localization content may control whether VAT numbers are considered relevant for invoice output in certain countries. For example, Japan uses a different tax ID format (Corporate Number), and UAE uses TRN (Tax Registration Number).

So please check the below areas:

Go to BP transaction or Manage Business Partner Master Data app. Check if Tax Number 1 or VAT Registration Number is maintained for customers in Japan, Indonesia, UAE. If not, update it manually or via data migration.

Identify the form used for invoice output (e.g., SD_BIL_INV or custom Adobe Form). Review the logic in the Data Provider Class or Form Interface. Modify the condition to include all relevant countries or remove country filtering entirely.

In Output Management, check if the form variant or template differs by country. Ensure the same form logic applies across all countries where VAT number is required.

SAP provides localized tax categories for Japan in the Business Partner master data like JP3 & JP4. Similarly, for UAE, SAP supports TRN as a localized tax field

entry.title: Re: Delivery Creation date VL10
entry.content:
VL10 transactions (like VL10B, VL10C, etc.) use delivery due date logic, which is based on delivery creation date ≤ planned delivery date. But here's the twist:

The Delivery Creation Date in VL10 is not a strict match filter. It’s a cutoff date.  SAP checks if the planned delivery date (from the schedule line) is less than or equal to this date.

  • When you use “equal to 15.08.2025”, SAP interprets this as “planned delivery date = 15.08.2025”, which may not match due to time stamps or internal rounding.
  • When you use “less than or equal to 15.08.2025”, SAP includes all items with planned delivery dates up to and including 15.08.2025 and this should work.
  • When you use “less than or equal to 14.08.2025”, the planned date is excluded.  So no items will be displayed.

Recommended approach is always use “less than or equal to” for the Delivery Creation Date in VL10. This ensures:

  • Items with planned delivery dates on or before the date are picked up.
  • You avoid issues with time stamps or internal scheduling buffers.

entry.title: Re: Supplier and Purchasing group email not picked in PO...
entry.content:
Even if the email addresses are correct, SAP might still fail if:

  • the sender email address is not mapped correctly in the Email Settings node.
  • The receiver email address is not being picked up due to missing or incorrect context mapping.
  • Go to Output Parameter Determination → Email Settings and verify Sender email is explicitly defined. Receiver email is mapped from the correct field (e.g., BusinessPartner.EmailAddress).
  • Check if the output type is configured to use EMAIL and not PRINT or XML by mistake.
  • SAP performs strict validation. Even small issues can trigger APOC_OR_MESSAGES105. Extra spaces before/after the email.
  • Hidden characters (especially if copy-pasted). Multiple addresses in one field without proper separators. It is better to use transaction BP or SU01 and manually retype the email address. Avoid copy-paste.


Finally, Run SLG1 with:

  • Object: APOC
  • Subobject: OR_MESSAGES
  • Date/time of the failed output

Check the full message context—it often includes the exact field or logic that failed.

Also try triggering the same output manually using Manage Output Items and see if the email is populated correctly. If it works manually but fails automatically, the issue is likely in the BRF+ determination logic.
